com.paypal.merchant.sdk
Interface PeripheralsManager

public interface PeripheralsManager

Peripherals Manager is the entry point for interacting with peripherals used for
credit card processing.
The PeripheralsManager lets the caller tap into feedback events from the underlying
peripheral without having to worry about the finer details of how the card readers work.
Typically, application developers would want to tap into peripherals related events together with
the TransactionManager related events to get more context. However, in some cases, apps may just
want to tap into the raw events from the Peripherals layer to implement more advanced functionality.

Method Summary
 ArrayList<PeripheralsListener.ReaderTypes> availableReaders()
          Allows the app (or other SDK internals) to discover what readers are available.
 void cancelWaitForAuthorization()
          This is API is used by other parts of the SDK as well as by applications to indicate that we are no longer
interested in listening for authorization events (such as doing a card swipe)
The TransactionManager internally puts the PeripheralsManager to "sleep" when a payment is cancelled or when the
application explicitly invokes the cancel APIs in the TransactionManager.
 void registerBluetoothPeripheral(android.bluetooth.BluetoothDevice device)
          Use this method to request that the SDK attempt to connect to a Bluetooth card reader
that the user might have selected using a UI defined in the app.

device.
 void waitForAuthorization()
          This API is used to indicate to the peripherals layer that the application is now interested in
scanning for card data through one of the connected devices.
 

Method Detail

availableReaders

ArrayList<PeripheralsListener.ReaderTypes> availableReaders()
Allows the app (or other SDK internals) to discover what readers are available.

Returns:
ArrayList an array of the different reader types that are currently
available. Currently available indicates that these devices are already paired/physically connected
etc.

waitForAuthorization

void waitForAuthorization()
This API is used to indicate to the peripherals layer that the application is now interested in
scanning for card data through one of the connected devices. Typically, applications do not have
to worry about controlling this as this part is taken care of automatically by the TransactionManager
However, this function is available should the app wish to take control of this timing on its own.
NOTE: if you decide to use this API rather than rely on the transaction manager to this automatically for you then make sure that this gets called before attempting a card swipe or a card insert into one of the
reader devices. Without invoking this call the peripherals layer will NOT listen for card data from the peripherals

cancelWaitForAuthorization

void cancelWaitForAuthorization()
This is API is used by other parts of the SDK as well as by applications to indicate that we are no longer
interested in listening for authorization events (such as doing a card swipe)
The TransactionManager internally puts the PeripheralsManager to "sleep" when a payment is cancelled or when the
application explicitly invokes the cancel APIs in the TransactionManager. This is an important step needed to ensure that
the battery in both these peripherals as well as in the mobile device is conserved.

registerPeripheralsListener

void registerPeripheralsListener(PeripheralsListener listener)
Use this method to register a custom listener to tap into the various events associated with the payment reader.

Parameters:
listener; - the listener interface defines the callbacks that will be invoked by the peripherals manager. Registering the same observer multiple times will simply get ignored and the observer will just be register once.

registerBluetoothPeripheral

void registerBluetoothPeripheral(android.bluetooth.BluetoothDevice device)
Use this method to request that the SDK attempt to connect to a Bluetooth card reader
that the user might have selected using a UI defined in the app.

Parameters:
device; - the Bluetooth payment reader that the listener hopes to talk to. Currently
this api is somewhat limited in the sense that, if the SDK has already identified a Bluetooth
payment reader that it can talk to when the SDK was first initialized, then the Bluetooth
device specified here will just be ignored (in the future, we will make the implementation
smarter but for the moment this is what we get).

unregisterPeripheralsListener

void unregisterPeripheralsListener(PeripheralsListener listener)
Use this method to unsubscribe from being notified of events related to the payment reader
device.

Parameters:
listener; - the observer object that was previously registered. No error will be returned
if the observer object was not previously register for notifications.
